column2: outgoing, very friendly; talkative, sociable
NATIVE: native, originating in a place
INTERNAL PERCEPTION: relating to the mind as the subject of experience, ex. Human emotions can only be experienced in a subjective manner; they are inexplicable to an outside observer.
CONTRADICTION: seeming contradiction OR an actual contradiction, ex. the paradox of time travel will be resolved when we learn more about the nature of space and time as a continuum.
IRREGULAR: irregular, unusual, ex. Darwin once said there is nothing more anomalous in nature than a bird that cannot fly.
THICK AND GOOEY: having a thick consistency, gelatinous, ex. honey is a viscous fluid
FLEETING: fleeting, of short life or duration, ex. sandcastles are an ephemeral art form, they only last until the next tide
CONFIRM: to confirm, to make certain, ex. Ethel could not find a witness to corroborate her alibi, so she was convicted on all counts.
INHERENT: implied, tacitly understood, ex. may constitutional scholars believe that the right of privacy is implicit in the Bill of Rights, even though it is nowhere stated as such.
CLEAR: clear, understandable, ex. Teddy was surprisingly lucid after the car wreck; I know I would have been babbling nonsense.
WASTEFUL: foolishly generous, not thrifty, ex. Katherine was being prodigal with her inheritance, rather than setting some of it aside for her old age.
PRETEND: to pretend, ex. Joe found it difficult to feign surprise when he had known all along what he was getting for Christmas; to fake an emotion
SEEMINGLY TRUE: having the deceptive look of truth, ex. The Senator seems to prefer a specious argument to a sound one, and a plausible statement to a truthful one.
RANDOM: random, capricious, impartial, ex. Theresa's decision to cast Bob rather than Fred in the leading role was purely arbitrary.

BOLD: bold, fearless, ex. Sara's intrepid plan to rescue the stranded hikers was frustrated by overly cautious park officials.; fearless; adventurous (often used for rhetorical or humorous effect), unafraid, undaunted, gallant, daring, bold, audacious, heroic, indomitable
HOSTILITY: hostility, enmity, ex. There was enormous antagonism between the amulets and the Montagues, resulting in great tragedy for their children.
DISLIKE: strong feeling against, dislike for, ex. Despite the fact that his whole family loved it, George had great antipathy towards broccoli.
BELIEF: firmly held belief, ex. It is a dogma of academia that if one does not publish papers, then one does not merit tenure.
RELEVANT: clearly relevant, ex. Gerald's discourse on the mating habits of chimpanzees was not pertinent to the class on cellular biology.
DIFFERENCE: difference, disagreement, ex. Megan's interpretation of the events of last night is at variance with the accounts of her friends.
NOT SUITED: not well matched, unsuited, ex. Because Albert smokes and Nell is a non-smoker, they are definitely incompatible as office-mates.
SEPARATE: to separate and make alone or single, ex. Scientists in France and the US vied to be the first to isolate the HIV virus.
CUT: to cut off completely, ex. The former junkie sought to sever his ties with his former friends who still used drugs.
UNIFICATION: the combination of diverse elements into one, ex. Walter's personality was a peculiar synthesis of flightiness and a great ability to concentrate on the task at hand.
CREATE: to create, foster, ex. Marjorie did her best to engender feelings of goodwill and community among the members of the club.
SEPARATE: distinct, separate, ex. The mathematics department is a discrete entity, and is not part of the College of Science and Engineering.
extremely talkative, ex. Hilary is a garrulous child; she just chatters constantly to anyone who will listen. (antonym: laconic)
"of few words, reticent, ex. Sam Rhode, ex. Calvin Coolidge was so famous for his laconic nature that he was nicknamed ""Silent Cal."" (antonym: garrulous)"
flim-flam, trickery, ex. The salesman's chicanery led to Terry's purchase of many items she did not need.
tending to stimulate, intriguing, ex. Provocative clothing
excess, extra, ex. After the party, the superfluous refreshments were taken to the children.
to use up, ex. expend energy
evil, having evil
an ideal/perfect model
negate, make invalid
complete, accomplish
difficult, strenous
happiness, pleasantness
very talented child
cunning, trickery
extremely clever, original
necessary, immediately important
restrict, confine
keep secret, contain, inhibit
give in, surrender, ex. The Confederate Army was more than ready to capitulate when Lee finally surrendered at the Appomattox Courthouse.
sycophantic, fawning
please, pacify, ex. A 6 year old having a tantrum cannot be placated; he will fuss long after you give him what he wants.
wealthy, ex. Adrienne was from a very affluent family, she never lacked for anything.
fanatical enthusiasm, ex. The zeal of the candidate's followers was so great as to be frightening at times.
restrain, forbid
malleability, stretchiness, ex. The modeling clay needed more water added to it in order to regain its plasticity.
one who has an attitude of contempt, distrust, ex. Those who break the law solely because others do so are the worst kind of cynic.
support, ex. Henry attempted to bolster his argument with irrelevant considerations and unfounded assumptions.
determined, faithful, ex. Kate was resolute in her decision to marry Keith.
one who appreciates fine things
in good taste, very proper, ex. At the garden party, the children were expected to behave in an appropriately decorous manner.
mild word of phrase substituted for an offensive one, ex. The politician's speech was full of euphemisms and buzzwords; he never said exactly what he meant.
overly scholarly, ex. Carroll was being pedantic by insisting on double checking every fact in the story.
pompous speech, ex. Although he said a few things of substance, the congressman's speech was mostly bombast.
one who hates humanity, ex. Lex was so angry at the whole world for so long that he has become a misanthrope.
to taunt, deride, ex. The crowd jeered at the pitcher after he walked three batters.
seemingly honest while not being so, ex. Clyde was disingenuous with his date when he asked if she wanted to see his etchings.
appropriateness, social acceptability, ex. The propriety of Miss Manners' behavior is above question.
one who hold unorthodox or unapproved beliefs, ex. Jones was considered a heretic by other economists for his radical views of economic growth.
genuine, trustworthy, ex. The feelings expressed by the suitors were undoubtable authentic.
relevant, to the point, ex. Gretchen's comments were apposite to the discussion, and clarified many points.
direct opposite, ex. Gail's ideas were the antithesis of good taste and discretion; her notions were downright vulgar.
not able to be untangled, ex. Marla found herself in inextricable difficulties, of which she could see no end.
beginning, budding, ex. Although she had taken only three lessons, Becky felt herself to be an incipient violinist.
to blend together, esp. a text, ex. Many scholars believe this classical epic is conflated, having been written in two distinct periods of ancient history.
number of members of a governing body necessary in order to proceed, ex. Not having a quorum present, the city council was unable to make a decision regarding the new ordinance.
deviating from the norm, ex. People see in his works a diseased and aberrant genius.
to count, to number, ex. The purpose of a census is to enumerate all of the residents of a country.
separation into two parts, ex. In some schools of ancient Greek philosophy, there was a dichotomy between body and spirit.
needing swift action, pressing, ex. There were more exigent (pressing) demands placed on Harriet's time than raising begonias.
not timely, inappropriate, ex. The door to door salesman could not have arrived at Marcia's house at a more inopportune moment than when she was in the shower.
promptness, eagerness, ex. Marcus left a generous tip for the waiter who had served us with a refreshing alacrity.
to suspend, as a meeting (should use this rather than convene..), ex. The board decided to adjourn until the following week.
stagnation, equilibrium, ex. Without research and interaction between institutions, the academic community would find itself in a condition of stasis.
unstable, open to change, ex. Andre's hypertension was considered labile; he was extremely susceptible to a heart attack.
state of balance, ex. The juggler held the bowling pin on her nose with perfect equilibrium.
an outlaw, one who is unconventional, ex. Although she had committed no crime, Mariana was considered a renegade because she refused to cooperate with the authorities.

"to replace; to supplant (supersede and replace ex. ""another discovery could supplant the original finding""), ex. Typewriters have gradually been superseded by word processors and personalized computers.; substitute for, take the place of (a person or thing previously in authority or use)"
originating, OR relating to seeds or semen, ex. Her work was considered seminal in the field of anthropology. The seminal fluid was frozen and preserved for later use.
negligible, having no effect, (null) ex. The additional expense of first class travel was nugatory for the corporate CEO.
not questionable, not doubtable, ex. Mother Theresa's opinions regarding Christian charity are unassailable.
limp, drooping, ex. The chef decided the noodles were overcooked because they were too flaccid for use in the lasagna.
in motion, ex. The pianist gave a dynamic performance that was extraordinarily energetic.
capable of living, capable of working, ex. a viable crop
barren, not cultivated or sown, ex. The cotton fields had to lie fallow every few years in order for the nutrients in the soil to replenish themselves.
inclination, ex. Cheryl had a propensity for lying about her accomplishments
to conspire, to be in secret sympathy with, ex. The historians have discovered that some of the villagers actually connived with the Nazis, while seeming to be neutral.
stubborn, defiant, ex. The recalcitrant teenager would not come out of his room except for meals and school.
pastoral, relating to country life, ex. Ginger wanted a bucolic cottage, with a white picket fence and a rose arbor.
everywhere, in all places, ex. If the tabloids are to be believed, Elvis is as ubiquitous as the air.
to adapt to a culture, assimilate, ex. Caroline found it difficult to become acculturated to her new environment.
to bloom, flourish, ex. The traffic of African slaves was beginning to burgeon as early as the beginning of the 18th century.
touching, adjacent to, with borders touching, ex. The Winthrops were proud of having visited all forty-eight contiguous states in the US.
a gap or fissure, ex. There was a rift the size of the Grand Canyon in their relationship. Ouch!
summarize, to repeat, to sum up, ex. The professor tried to recapitulate her entire lecture in the last five minutes of class
not solid, weak, ex. Mathilda had a very tenuous grasp of the concepts discussed in her philosophy class.
low point, point opposite the zenith, ex. The has-been actor felt he was at the nadir of his career when he performed at children's birthday parties as a juggler and clown.
basic, ex. Reading and writing are very rudimentary skills in everyday living.
lying down, resting, ex. Matisse painted several masterpieces showing recumbent figures.

a supporting piece of a structure (n) OR to strengthen, support (v), ex. The buttresses on the south side of the cathedral were deteriorating with age. Yolanda attempted to buttress her argument with irrelevant considerations and personal attacks.
to change from one place or mode to another, ex. Gary needed to transpose the violin sonata so that he could play it on his cello.
false front, ex. His composure was merely a facade; inside he was actually grief stricken.
outside, surrounding, auxiliary, ex. The church's youth group had a peripheral organization for junior teens.
to cluster, to form a nucleus/center, ex. The dust bunnies under the bed seem to nucleate until they become dust elephants.
layer, ex. The archaeologists were working in the fifth strata beneath the ancient city.
twisty, winding, tricky, convoluted, ex. The staircase carved into the cliff face was a tortuous climb, with many hazards along the way.
to stripe, ex. striated muscles, The massive floods would striate the banks of the river with debris and silt.
to obstruct, block up, ex. The cave passage was occluded by the rubble left by the cave-in.
asleep, inactive, ex. The larvae of the 17 year cicada lie dormant underground for 16 years, emerging in the 17th year to mate and lay eggs.

happy, prosperous, peaceful (happy days :)- CANADA)(adj.), ex. Anna felt that the years she spent living and working in the northwestern wilderness were the halcyon years of her life, Canada bird studies were the halcyon time of my life.
quiet, calm, ex. Lake Placid, The waters of the lake were once again placid after the storm had passed.
pimpstep
(ambulance)
to turn away, to avoid (aversion- avoidance), ex. Lydia tried to avert her eyes from the accident scene.
wandering, traveling, ex. Kyle spent four years as an errant missionary, traveling throughout Asia and the south Pacific.
to come together, merge, ex. Even though we know they remain parallel, the railroad tracks appear to converge on the horizon.
exit, (digress- move away from, Egress- exit, leave), ex. As their fingers slipped on the smooth granite walls, the climbers began to realize there was no egress from the deep valley.
a chaotic mess, confusion, ex. Amid a welter of competing interests, Elisa found herself more and more confused.
lukewarm, room temperature, ex. Because he had let it sit out for several hours, Charles' coffee was tepid.
to burden, ex. His irresponsible actions only served to encumber his parents with excessive debt.
not porous, not allowing flow-through, ex. The Berlin Wall, condoms, hopefully; The lining of the landfill must be impermeable, so that toxic substances will not leak through.
hardened, unsympathetic, ex. The politician did not want to appear callous toward the plight of the earthquake victims.
adaptability, springiness, ex. A toddler has a surprising amount of elasticity when it comes to a changing living situation.
controllable, cooperative, agreeing, ex. As a group, the students were not very tractable, but individually the dean was able to get them to change their position.
flowery, or reddish, ex. Shelley's new linens had a florid design, with cabbage roses and lilies predominating. Eric's face was florid with excitement.
having shiny rainbow colors, shimmery, ex. The oil slick was iridescent as it reflected the light on the water.
multi-colored and blotchy (adj), ex. When she came down with the measles, her face was pied with rose-ola rash.

to speckle or fleck, esp. with paint (v) OR the effect of many dots, ex. Seurat was famous for stippling the canvas to create his unique effect. His paintings were prime examples of stipple taken to its highest degree of artistry.
abstract, supernatural, ex. She believed that the prohibition against murder was both universal and transcendental, having a place in every human society, and therefore ordained by God.
intangible, not physical, not able to be touched, ex. John Kennedy's charisma, although impalpable, can still be conveyed through the medium of old film footage.
a single, huge structure, or a large organization acting as one force (n), ex. The mega-corporation was viewed by outsiders as an impenetrable monolith. Easter Island.
to add water to, ex, To hydrate the chemical compound would cause an explosive reaction.
lotion that moisturizes, (mollify-sooth), ex. After spending the day at sea, Jessica needed to apply some emollient to her face.
with iron (Fe2+), ex. The ferrous deposits in the region made it difficult to navigate with a compass.
muddy, obscured, ex. The turbid waters of the flooded creek made it difficult for the fisherman to see any fish.
dry, ex. The soil in the plant pots had become completely arid from neglect.
to supply or combine with oxygen or air (v), ex. The egg whites are aerated until they are stiff when one makes meringue.

to revive, renew, ex. Trevor attempted to resuscitate the failing business, but no one was interested in buying used widgets (a small gadget or mechanical device, especially one whose name is unknown or unspecified).
animal remains, ex. Vultures carry, The buzzards circled around the carrion (carcass) until traffic was light enough to let them land and dine.
uninteresting, without liveliness, ex. Dad, He was probably the most vapid entertainer she had ever laid eyes on; dry.
sweet, sentimental, ex. to receive coitus ;), The smell of the perfume shop was cloying and overwhelming, walking into Bath and Body Works
strong tasting or smelling, ex. garlic, The new Tex-Mex restaurant has a great salsa that is pungent and tasty.
"aromatic, having an odor, ""smells of"" ex. The forest was redolent of pine needles and other woodsy smells."

"stated or appearing to be true, but not necessarily so, ex. ""the delay may have a deeper cause than the ostensible reason""; apparent, under a pretext (adj), ex. The structure was an ostensible storefront, but in reality it was a speakeasy. Apparent, outward, superficial, professed, supposed, alleged, purported."
argument, strife (n), ex. Whenever he came to visit, Uncle Rupert caused discord and family quarrels.
foolish, silly (adj), ex. The campers were being foolhardy in their fatuous disregard for danger from the swollen stream.
silly, empty-headed (adj), ex. Lloyd certainly had some inane ideas about what to do on a date.
ridiculous, absurd, ex. The music of ludicrous is absurd/ludicrous. The idea that Mother Theresa is in her line of work for the money is ludicrous in the extreme.

to ponder, to think harder, ex. Ursula needed plenty of time in order to cogitate and come up with a decision about her marriage. Trinity is a school which continually encourages students to cogitate on new material.
to study thoroughly (backwards of pursue a passion; must study thoroughly to pursue) (v), ex. Frank intended to peruse the entire economics textbook, in order to prepare for his exam.
keen, mentally sharp, (perceptive), ex. After waking up early and eating a good breakfast, Jim felt particularly perspicacious and ready for school.
creed, belief, ex. Some of the early American sects held the doctrine that musical instruments were evil.
unsophisticatedness, artlessness, ex. Heather displayed an unusual degree of naivet√© when confronted with her wrongdoings
to contradict, to give false cover to, masked, covered up, ex. Her smiling face belied the fact that she felt devastated and grief stricken.
not believable, ex. The story Honoria made up about her whereabouts last night was totally implausible.
like a pontiff, a pope, extremely authoritative (adj), ex. Gilbert was given to making pontifical pronouncements to his employees.
a large vehicle that crushes anything in its path, ex. a Hummer, Gwendolyn was like a juggernaut in her desire for success and fame; she did not let anyone get in her way.
to condemn, to forbid, (rather than prescribe or permit/suggest, proscribe or forbid), ex. Some people felt it is archaic for the church to proscribe divorce.

to disapprove, condemn, OR disapproval, condemnation (v,n), ex. The school board voted to censure the wayward (stubborn, disobedient) teacher. Martin could not bear the censure he felt from his parents.
without fear of punishment (n), ex. George knew he could spend his friend's money with impunity.
one who likes to eat a lot (n), (gourmet), ex. The restaurant offered an all you can eat menu, and was overwhelmed by hungry gourmands.
austere, disciplined (adj), ex. The lifestyle at the monastery was extremely ascetic, without many worldly pleasures.
one who lives for pleasure, ex. Hugh Hefner/Playboy mansion episode. The island paradise was populated by hedonists, who enjoyed the pleasures of the senses.
extravagant, prodigal, ex. It was unwise to be so profligate with your savings; you should keep it for a rainy day.
stubborn, unfeeling, ex. With respect to the besotted young swain's amorous feelings, Camille was completely obdurate, she had no feelings for him at all.
traitor (n), ex. Benedict Quisling Arnold ;), Henry was considered a quisling by his football club for giving information to their rivals.
